column4: If you do an ./configure --prefix=whatever are you stuck with it forever?
not really, but it makes uninstallation of that package quite messy - not advisable
I did a sudo make uninstall - but seem to be stuck with it
test -z "/usr/local/classpath/lib/classpath" || mkdir -p -- "/usr/local/classpath/lib/classpath"
you could install the other version of classpath in a chrooted environment
what is a "chrooted environment"?
a chroot is like a contained directory, with it's own root (/) where you can have another installation of linux and a whole different set of packages
I found https://help.ubuntu.com/6.10/ubuntu/packagingguide/C/appendix-chroot.html but that confuses me more
Is ubuntu so different to other Linux versions?  setting prefix and path are not an option with ubuntu?
not at all - it just appears that classpath does not like being installed to a different prefix
Then how do I check what I have set as a prefix? and how can I unset the prefix?
usually, to ./configure, you pass --prefix=/path/to/whatever  -- but you might have to do more, check the options to configure.   ./configure --help
But afterwards ... how can you check what the prefix is actually set to? After make uninstall I don't understand why its wanting an old prefix
you need to specify the prefix to the uninstall target because by default, it assumes, you have installed classpath to the default regular location, but you havent
Thanks - I going to try to uninstall every classpath and start over... but I think I hearing - remember your prefix, there is no variable to check?

that would be correct, there is no way of telling afterwards what the prefix was you used -- which is why i suggest you use a chroot to install the other version of classpath to, that way, you can use the default prefix

think of a chroot as a seperate room in your house - with it's own kitchen, living-room, spare-room, etc -- a house within a house - what you do inside the room makes little impact on the rest of the house
what's the difference between mark for removal and mark for complete removal? (search in help didnt help)
in the former, only the package's contents are deleted, in the latter, the configuration files are also removed
and Nicke thanks - so I want a complete removal at this one
(and others) thanks - off to try the suggestions
